Java is a platform-independent, object-oriented programming language that runs on the JVM and is commonly used for backend, enterprise, and Android development.
Platform-independent (how to explain it)
What it means

Platform-independent means Java programs can run on different operating systems without changing the code.

How it works (key point interviewers want)

Java code is compiled into bytecode, not machine code.
That bytecode runs on the Java Virtual Machine (JVM), and each OS has its own JVM implementation.

One-line example

Write once, run anywhere â€” as long as a JVM exists.

Strong interview phrasing

Java is platform-independent because it compiles to bytecode, which is executed by the JVM rather than the operating system directly.

Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) in Java
What it means

Object-oriented programming organizes code around objects that represent real-world entities and behavior.

It helps make our code reusable, organized, and easier to maintain which is important for large scale systems by following OOP concepts
The 4 pillars (say them confidently)


Encapsulation â€“  is the practice of protecting and organizing code inside a class.


Inheritance â€“ reuse and extend existing code


Polymorphism â€“ adds flexibility- allows objects to take multiple forms;


Abstraction â€“ hide complexity, expose only whatâ€™s needed


Strong interview phrasing

Java uses OOP principles to make code modular, reusable, and easier to maintain, which is important for large-scale systems.

Class vs Object

A class is a blueprint or template that defines properties and behaviors, while an object is a real instance of that class created at runtime.

General-Knowledge/Java/5.-Java-Modifiers.content:
What

Modifiers are keywords in Java that change the behavior or accessibility of classes, methods, and variables.


Access modifiers control visibility: public, protected, private, and package-private (default).


Non-access modifiers change behavior: static, final, abstract, synchronized, volatile, etc.




Access Modifiers
What:

Control visibility of classes, methods, and variables.


public â†’ accessible everywhere


private â†’ accessible only inside the class


protected â†’ accessible in subclasses and same package


default (no keyword) â†’ accessible only in the same package



Why:

To protect data, enforce encapsulation, and control which parts of code can access members.

Non-Access Modifiers in Java
What

Non-access modifiers change the behavior or properties of classes, methods, or variables without affecting visibility.
Examples: static, final, abstract, synchronized, volatile, transient, native.


Why

They allow you to:



Define shared data (static)


Create constants (final)


Specify abstract behavior (abstract)


Ensure thread safety (synchronized, volatile)


Optimize or interact with JVM (transient, native)


In short: they control functionality, not access.
How

Static â†’ belongs to the class, not instances

class Counter {     static int count = 0;  // Shared among all objects }

Final â†’ constant value, cannot be changed

final double PI = 3.1416;

Abstract â†’ defines a method/class without implementation

abstract class Shape {     abstract void draw(); }

Synchronized â†’ thread-safe method

synchronized void increment() { count++; }

1ï¸âƒ£  Why Map is faster?

Map is faster for retrieving by key because it uses a hash table (or tree) internally, so lookup is O(1) on average, while List lookup by value is O(n) unless you already know the index.

List has no concept of keys; you must search through elements.

userMap.put("user123", "Alice");

String name = userMap.get("user456"); // O(1) average


Map calculates a hash for the key, finds the value directly.

What
Functional interfaces are interfaces with a single abstract method, which allows us to pass lambdas or method references.
Why
Functional interfaces let us use lambdas. You could create your own, but standard ones are preferred because theyâ€™re readable, standard, and work directly with Streams.â€
+----------------+----------------+--------------------------+
| Interface      | Input          | Output                   |
+----------------+----------------+--------------------------+
| Predicate<T>   | T              | boolean                  |
| Function<T,R>  | T              | R                        |
| Consumer<T>    | T              | void                     |
| Supplier<T>    | none           | T                        |
| BinaryOperator | T, T           | T                        |
+----------------+----------------+--------------------------+

1ï¸âƒ£ Predicate <â€˜Tâ€™>

Represents a boolean-valued function (a test/condition)

Method:
boolean test(T t)
Example: Filter users older than 18

List<User> adults = users.stream()
                         .filter(isAdult)

Interview Tip:

Used for conditions, usually with filter, anyMatch, allMatch.

2ï¸âƒ£ Function<T, R>

Represents a function that takes an input T and returns a result R

R apply(T t)

List<String> names = users.stream()
                          .map(getName)
                          .collect(Collectors.toList());


Interview Tip:

Used for transformations, usually with map.

3ï¸âƒ£ Consumer<â€˜Tâ€™>

Represents an operation that consumes a value but returns nothing

Method:
void accept(T t)
Example: Print all users

users.forEach(printUser);

Interview Tip:

Used when performing actions like printing, logging, or modifying something externally.

4ï¸âƒ£ Supplier<â€˜Tâ€™>

Represents a supplier of results, i.e., produces a value without any input

Method:
T get()
Example: Generate a random number

System.out.println(random.get());

Useful for top-N questions, sampling, or limiting results

Terminal Operations: Collect & Collectors
collect() is used to gather results from a stream.
Java provides Collectors to define how to collect data.
a) Collect to List or Set
List<String> namesList = users.stream()
                              .map(User::getName)
                              .collect(Collectors.toList());

Set<String> namesSet = users.stream()
                            .map(User::getName)
                            .collect(Collectors.toSet());

Tip: List preserves order, Set removes duplicates.
b) Collect to Map
Map<String, Integer> userAgeMap = users.stream()
                                      .collect(Collectors.toMap(
                                          User::getName,   // key
                                          User::getAge     // value
                                      ));

c) groupingBy() â€” Group Elements
Example: Group users by department
Map<String, List<User>> byDept =  
	users.stream().collect(Collectors.groupingBy(User::getDepartment));

Result: "HR" -> List of HR users, "IT" -> List of IT users
d) partitioningBy() â€” Split by Predicate
Example: Users older than 25
Map<Boolean, List<User>> partitioned = users.stream()
        .collect(Collectors.partitioningBy(u -> u.getAge() > 25));

Result:

true â†’ users older than 25
false â†’ users 25 or younger

e) joining() â€” Combine Strings
String namesJoined = users.stream()
                          .map(User::getName)
                          .collect(Collectors.joining(", "));

System.out.println(namesJoined); // Alice, Bob, Charlie

f) counting() â€” Count Elements
long count = users.stream()
                  .filter(u -> u.getAge() > 25)
                  .collect(Collectors.counting());

System.out.println(count); // Number of users older than 25

g) summarizingInt() â€” Stats in One Go
IntSummaryStatistics stats = users.stream()
                                  .collect(Collectors.summarizingInt(User::getAge));

System.out.println(stats.getMax());   // Max age
System.out.println(stats.getMin());   // Min age
System.out.println(stats.getAverage()); // Average age
System.out.println(stats.getCount());   // Count

h) reduce() â€” General Aggregation
reduce() takes many values and reduces them into a single value.
int totalAge = users.stream()
                    .map(User::getAge)
                    .reduce(0, Integer::sum);
  
  
This version of `reduce` has two parts: 
reduce(identity, accumulator)
  
|Part          |        Meaning          |
|--------------|-------------------------|
|`0`           |Identity (starting value)|
|`Integer::sum`|How to combine two values| 


reduce can combine elements into a single result using a binary function.

Optional<User> oldest = users.stream()
                    .reduce((u1, u2) -> u1.getAge() > u2.getAge() ? u1 : u2);
   
This version has no identity value:
reduce(BinaryOperator<T>)

For common cases, prefer built-ins:
int sum = users.stream().mapToInt(User::getAge).sum();

Optional<User> oldest = users.stream().max(Comparator.comparing(User::getAge));

These are:

Clearer
Less error-prone
More readable in interviews

This:

is equivalent to:

And that is equivalent to:
Collections.sort(users, (u1, u2) -> u1.getAge() - u2.getAge());

Ascending vs Descending
Ascending (default)

Descending
.sorted(Comparator.comparing(User::getAge).reversed())

Sorting by multiple fields (very common interview question)

Real-world analogy (easy to remember)
ğŸ¢ Process = Office Building
ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ Threads = Employees inside

In Java:

Each Java application runs in **one JVM process
JVM process contains **multiple threads

JIT compiler thread(s)

When you write:

With threads:

Example

Thread Lifecycle (Know the States)
States (high level)

NEW â€“ created but not started
RUNNABLE â€“ ready or running
BLOCKED / WAITING â€“ waiting for resource
TERMINATED â€“ finished execution

Quick Lifecycle Story (30s Script)

â€œA thread starts in the NEW state. Calling start() moves it to RUNNABLE, where the scheduler decides when it runs. It may become BLOCKED or WAITING if waiting for resources or another thread. Once run() finishes, it enters TERMINATED. Important methods include start(), sleep(), join(), and interrupt(). Calling run() directly does not start a new thread â€” thatâ€™s a common trap.â€

class MyThread extends Thread {
    public void run() {
        System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + " is running");
    }
}

public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {
        MyThread t1 = new MyThread();
        System.out.println("State after creation: " + t1.getState()); // NEW
        t1.start();
        System.out.println("State after start: " + t1.getState());    // RUNNABLE
        t1.join(); // Wait for t1 to finish
        System.out.println("State after join: " + t1.getState());     // TERMINATED
    }
}

What
Big O notation is a way to describe how the runtime or memory usage of an algorithm grows as the input size increases.
â€œThere are millions of ways to solve a problem, itâ€™s important to identify what is good, better, and bestâ€ ~Harvard CS50

Common Big O





















































Big ONameExampleNotesO(1)ConstantAccessing an array elementFastest, independent of input sizeO(log n)LogarithmicBinary searchEfficient, grows slowlyO(n)LinearSimple loop over arrayGrows proportionally with inputO(n log n)LinearithmicMerge sort, quicksort (average)Common for efficient sortingO(nÂ²)QuadraticNested loopsSlow for large inputsO(2^n)ExponentialRecursive FibonacciBecomes infeasible quicklyO(n!)FactorialTraveling salesman brute forceExtremely slow, only for tiny inputs
Example Problem
Phonebook with 1000 pages, find â€œNINAâ€
Solution 1: Flip each page
O(n)
Good - It proportionally grows with input
Solution 2: Flip by 2 pages
O(n/2)
Better - Yes, n/2 is smaller than n, but as n grows, both grow linearly.
Solution 3: Divide the book by half, decide which half is closer to â€œNINAâ€, discard the other halfâ€¦ repeat till one page is left with â€œNINAâ€

General-Knowledge/System-Design/Kafka.title: Kafka
General-Knowledge/System-Design/Kafka.content:
open-source distributed event streaming platform
What

Message Queue -  a system where messages are stored until they are consumed. Each message is typically processed by only one consumer.
Ideal for task delivery guarantees that only needs to be processed once
Stream - continuous flow of data that can be processed in real time by multiple consumers.
- multiple independent consumers that process the same data differently (e.g., one consumer updates a dashboard, another updates a database).
- Pub-Sub (can be multiple subscribers), ideal for analytics

Why Kafka?

Fault Tolerant
a. Leader-Follower Partitions for backup
b. Retry and error
High Availability
Can easily scale by
1. Adding more Brokers (physical servers)
2. Good partition key design - to evenly distribute load

Flow
A. Producer send message and specify the topic and partition
Topic - Logical group of partitions/data, can have multiple partition

Partition - "queue" of ordered immutable sequence of messages
	- Kafka strategy to scale as they allow for messages to be consumed in parallel.

B. Broker / Server receives the message
C. Consumer subscribes to the topic
With consumer groups, each event is guaranteed to only be processed by one consumer in the group.

Important:
1. Consumer internally track the offset where it stopped
2. Once consumer consumes the message it responds to the broker the offset â€œI finished reading offset 99â€
3. Broker also keeps track of the offset for backup purposes incase consumer is down
Optimization Strategy

Producer can batch send message
Producer can compress message before sending

Logs Retention Policy
Defaults to 7 days
 When log file reaches 1 GB
